s.text: (Actually, there is no "sell immediately" recommendation, though common wisdom on the Street is that you should do so if bodies begin falling past your windows.)
In a market where tomorrow seems like the long term, the fact that 10 years from now the mouse will still be roaring somehow just doesn't really matter.
In a market where tomorrow seems like the long term, the fact that 10 years from now the mouse will still be roaring somehow just doesn't really matter.
In the 1970s and early 1980s, Marxist thinkers were fond of using the phrase "late capitalism" to describe the American economy.
You don't hear much about "late capitalism" these days, except insofar as it has morphed, oddly, into the techno-utopianism of New Economy advocates.

But what we should start hearing about more and more is our own "late bull market," which seems somehow simultaneously frothy and exhausted.

2 billion to the NFL for the exclusive rights to Monday and Sunday Night Football, and they may not have the ratings to justify that.

ABC is certainly doing its best to put a smiling face on its recent woes.
What happened testifies partly to the continued power of analysts on Wall Street but also to the fact that at these heights, it's very easy to become suddenly--and often justifiably--afraid.
(Actually, there is no "sell immediately" recommendation, though common wisdom on the Street is that you should do so if bodies begin falling past your windows.)

That analogy is inexact, since investors have been more than willing to give many companies the benefit of the doubt, but those companies tend to be either Internet stocks, cancer-drug companies, or merger candidates.
